item.title: Hegseth Ordered Lethal Boat Strike but Not the Killing of Survivors, Officials Say
item.description: Amid talk of war crimes, the details and precise sequence of a Sept. 2 attack on a boat in the Caribbean are facing intensifying scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The suggestion that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth or his officials targeted shipwrecked survivors has been galvanizing because that would apparently be a war crime even if one accepts Trump officials’ broader argument for the strike campaign.

item.title: For Trump, Hegseth’s Approach to Venezuela Strikes Is a Growing Liability
item.description: Investigations are mounting into the legality of strikes that have killed scores of people in the waters off Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth with President Trump in the Oval Office earlier this year.

item.title: Trump’s Crackdown in Wake of Shooting Blocks Legal Pathways for Migrants
item.description: The new measures represent some of the most significant changes to immigration policy since President Trump returned to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz, Jazmine Ulloa and Allison McCann
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A small memorial left at the scene of the shooting of two National Guard members in Washington last week.

item.title: As Trump Deepens Immigration Crackdown, Exceptions Disappear for Afghans and Others
item.description: President Trump’s latest changes to the immigration system affect communities that traditionally have been considered special cases.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Last week, the Trump administration announced it would stop issuing visas to people from Afghanistan and review all Afghans allowed into the United States during the Biden administration.

item.title: Trump Administration Fires 8 Immigration Judges in New York
item.description: The firings, part of a nationwide effort, felt “like a Monday afternoon massacre,” said one judge who lost her job last month.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley
item.media:description: Federal agents have been arresting immigrants after court hearings in Manhattan.

item.title: After Trump’s M.R.I. Claim, His Doctor’s Memo Offers Little Clarity
item.description: While the president said he had a M.R.I. exam, a physician’s memo released by the White House was less specific.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The statement, by Dr. Sean P. Barbabella, said the tests on President Trump’s cardiovascular system and abdominal region showed the president “remains in excellent overall health.”

item.title: Putin to Meet With Trump’s Envoy as U.S. Pushes for Ukraine Deal
item.description: In Moscow, Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, is expected to present President Vladimir V. Putin with a revised proposal to end the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, speaking to reporters outside the White House in February. He is scheduled to be in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Zelensky Turns to Europe After Talks With U.S. Officials
item.description: Ukraine’s president met with President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday as Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, was traveling to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and President Emmanuel Macron of France met in Paris on Monday as part of a flurry of diplomatic talks to end the war with Russia.

item.title: A Surprise When Your Package Arrives: You Have to Pay the Tariff
item.description: The end of a tariff exemption on goods worth $800 or less has left some U.S. shoppers with an extra shipping bill that must be paid before delivery.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Batten purchased her coat from a Dutch retailer. After it shipped, she learned she’d need to pay over $250 in customs duties.

item.title: To Avoid Pharma Tariffs, U.K. Agrees to Trump’s Demand to Pay More for Drugs
item.description: President Trump has complained that wealthy countries like Britain pay too little for drugs, leading America to bear much of the burden of the costs of medicines.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: A lab run by the drugmaker AstraZeneca. President Trump has complained that wealthy European countries pay too little for medicines.

item.title: Trump Becomes the Wild Card in Razor-Thin Honduras Election
item.description: President Trump warned that if his favored candidate didn’t win, the United States would “not be throwing good money after bad” at the country.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign poster for Nasry Asfura, the right-wing candidate backed by President Trump, last month on a street in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

item.title: Son of El Chapo Pleads Guilty to Kidnapping Father’s Former Cartel Partner
item.description: Joaquín Guzmán López admitted to having the once-untouchable drug kingpin Ismael Zambada García abducted and flown to the United States, among a sweeping set of other crimes.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Robert Chiarito
item.media:description: A plane believed to have been used to kidnap the drug kingpin Ismael Zambada García in Santa Teresa, N.M., last year.

item.title: Hong Kong Contractors Used Unsafe Netting at Fire Site, Officials Say
item.description: Investigators say contractors wrapped the buildings in substandard scaffolding netting and then sought to hide it from inspectors. The toll from the fire rose to 151.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong and Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Green netting and bamboo scaffolding are visible on buildings at Wang Fuk Court, the Hong Kong apartment complex engulfed by fire last week.

item.title: The Transgender Cancer Patient and What She Heard on Tape
item.description: Jennifer Capasso had endured multiple tumors. She wondered what might be said during her next cancer surgery. So, she hit record on her phone.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Capasso was about to undergo another cancer operation. It frustrated her that she was unconscious as the surgeon removed each tumor.

item.title: TSA Imposes $45 Fee for Travelers Without REAL ID Starting February 2026
item.description: As of February, passengers without the government-approved identity card will be required to pay for alternative screening at U.S. airports.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: A T.S.A. worker checks a traveler’s ID at the international airport in Oakland, Calif.

item.title: This Year, a Smaller Christmas at the White House
item.description: The White House is decorated in a classic red-and-green Christmas theme. But with the East Wing reduced to rubble, there are fewer decorations this year.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi and Allison Robbert
item.media:description: A portrait of President Trump made out of Legos in the Green Room of the White House.

item.title: Winter Storm Expected to Slam Northeast U.S. With Heavy Snow
item.description: Whether snow falls in major cities Tuesday will depend on the nor’easter’s path.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young, Nazaneen Ghaffar and Judson Jones
item.media:description: Snow covered cars at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago on Sunday. More winter weather was expected in the Northeast on Monday night and Tuesday.

item.title: Russian Launch Site Mishap Leaves Country’s Space Program in Limbo
item.description: The ability of Russia to launch astronauts to the International Space Station remains in limbo after an incident last week at the Baikonur base in Kazakhstan.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A Soyuz spacecraft launching from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Nov. 27. The rocket itself headed to space without problem, but the rocket’s exhaust knocked a service platform out of its protective shelter.

item.title: Olivia Nuzzi Isn’t Telling All
item.description: Olivia Nuzzi doesn’t seem to recognize that her collaboration with Robert Kennedy was a grave professional betrayal.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Japan’s New Clarity on Taiwan Is a Wake-Up Call
item.description: The Japanese leader’s candor over Taiwan brought the shared regional stakes out into the open, and the U.S. must stand behind its ally.
item.dc:creator: Craig Singleton

item.title: Starbucks to Pay $39 Million in Landmark N.Y.C. Labor Law Settlement
item.description: Starbucks agreed to the settlement after failing to give workers stable schedules. Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect, joined striking Starbucks workers in Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.category: Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (NYC)

item.title: Floods in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Vietnam Have Killed Over 1,200. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Unusually destructive storms have killed more than 1,200 people across the region and displaced millions in South and Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg, Muktita Suhartono and Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:description: A village affected by a flash flood in Batang Toru, North Sumatra, Indonesia, on Monday.

item.title: Reginald T. Jackson, A.M.E. Bishop With Political Power, Dies at 71
item.description: Influential up and down the Eastern Seaboard, he was part of a long tradition among Black clergy of fighting bias and getting out the vote. “No vote, no clout,” he’d say.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bishop Reginald Jackson in 2024. As head of one of the country’s largest majority-Black denominations, he was a leading figure at the intersection of religion and Black electoral politics.
